translation.text: Basant, Fifth Mehl:

melody.description: There is no melody or mood associated with this line, which may be because it is the preamble to the hymn, or is not meant to be read in any particular melody or mood

author.author: None
author.description: There is no author associated with this line, as it may be the preamble to the hymn

translation.text: You gave us our soul, breath of life and body.

melody.description: Basant denotes the changing of the season and the newness of spring. This Raag encourages the mind to brush away its selfishness, just like spring-cleaning removes all the cobwebs and creates a fresh start. There are feelings of hope and expectation of a new beginning and the start of a new cycle. However, these emotions are not dependent on the physical change of the season, but are an encouragement of an internal effort to change.

author.author: Guru Arjan Dev
author.description:
Guru Arjan Dev [1563 - 1606] was the fifth Guru of the Sikhs, born at Goindval. He was the youngest of the three sons of Guru Ram Das, the fourth Sikh Guru.

Guru Arjan Dev finished the construction of the Harimandir Sahib, the Golden Temple, and compiled the first Sikh scripture, known as the Adi Granth. Shortly after he became the first martyr of the Sikh religion, which formed a turning point in the development of the faith.

translation.text: I am a fool, but You have made me beautiful, enshrining Your Light within me.

melody.description: Basant denotes the changing of the season and the newness of spring. This Raag encourages the mind to brush away its selfishness, just like spring-cleaning removes all the cobwebs and creates a fresh start. There are feelings of hope and expectation of a new beginning and the start of a new cycle. However, these emotions are not dependent on the physical change of the season, but are an encouragement of an internal effort to change.

author.author: Guru Arjan Dev

translation.text: We are all beggars, O God; You are merciful to us.

translation.text: Chanting the Naam, the Name of the Lord, we are uplifted and exalted. ||1||

translation.text: and cause all to be done. ||1||Pause||

text: ਸਦਾ ਰਿਦੈ ਜਪੀ ਪ੍ਰਭ ਤੇਰੋ ਨਾਮੁ ॥੩॥

translation.text: May I always chant and meditate within my heart on Your Name, O God. ||3||

transliteration.text: sadā ridai japī prabh tērō nām .3.

text: ਸਭੁ ਤੇਰੋ ਖੇਲੁ ਤੁਝ ਮਹਿ ਸਮਾਹਿ ॥

translation.text: Everything is Your play; it all merges again into You.

transliteration.text: sabh tērō khēl tujh mah samāh .

translation.text: My Beloved God, my King is with me.

text: ਜਾ ਕੈ ਸਿਮਰਨਿ ਦੁਖੁ ਨ ਹੋਇ ॥

translation.text: Remembering Him in meditation, there is no pain or suffering.

transliteration.text: jā kai simaran dukh n hōi .

translation.text: Please, take pity on me, and lead me on to meet Him. ||1||

text: ਜੀਉ ਪ੍ਰਾਨ ਸਭੁ ਤੇਰੋ ਧਨ ॥੧॥ ਰਹਾਉ ॥

translation.text: This soul, breath of life, and wealth are all Yours, O Lord. ||1||Pause||

transliteration.text: jīu prān sabh tērō dhan .1. rahāu .

melody.description: Basant denotes the changing of the season and the newness of spring. text: ਜਾ ਕਉ ਖੋਜਹਿ ਸੁਰਿ ਨਰ ਦੇਵ ॥

translation.text: He is sought by the angels, mortals and divine beings.

transliteration.text: jā kau khōjah sur nar dēv .

melody.description: Basant denotes the changing of the season and the newness of spring. This Raag encourages the mind to brush away its selfishness, just like spring-cleaning removes all the cobwebs and creates a fresh start. text: ਮੁਨਿ ਜਨ ਸੇਖ ਨ ਲਹਹਿ ਭੇਵ ॥

translation.text: The silent sages, the humble, and the religious teachers do not understand His mystery.

transliteration.text: mun jan sēkh n lahah bhēv .

melody.description: Basant denotes the changing of the season and the newness of spring. This Raag encourages the mind to brush away its selfishness, just like spring-cleaning removes all the cobwebs and creates a fresh start. text: ਜਾ ਕੀ ਗਤਿ ਮਿਤਿ ਕਹੀ ਨ ਜਾਇ ॥

translation.text: His state and extent cannot be described.

transliteration.text: jā kī gat mit kahī n jāi .

text: ਘਟਿ ਘਟਿ ਘਟਿ ਘਟਿ ਰਹਿਆ ਸਮਾਇ ॥੨॥

translation.text: In each and every home of each and every heart, He is permeating and pervading. ||2||

transliteration.text: ghat ghat ghat ghat rahiā samāi .2.

melody.description: Basant denotes the changing of the season and the newness of spring. author.description:
Guru Arjan Dev [1563 - 1606] was the fifth Guru of the Sikhs, born at Goindval. He was the youngest of the three sons of Guru Ram Das, the fourth Sikh Guru.

Guru Arjan Dev finished the construction of the Harimandir Sahib, the Golden Temple, and compiled the first Sikh scripture, known as the Adi Granth. Shortly after he became the first martyr of the Sikh religion, which formed a turning point in the development of the faith.

text: ਹਉ ਕਛੂ ਨ ਜਾਨਉ ਤੇਰੀ ਸਾਰ ॥

translation.text: I do not understand anything of Your Worth.

transliteration.text: hau kashū n jānau tērī sār .

melody.description: Basant denotes the changing of the season and the newness of spring. This Raag encourages the mind to brush away its selfishness, just like spring-cleaning removes all the cobwebs and creates a fresh start. There are feelings of hope and expectation of a new beginning and the start of a new cycle. However, these emotions are not dependent on the physical change of the season, but are an encouragement of an internal effort to change.

author.author: Guru Arjan Dev
author.description:
Guru Arjan Dev [1563 - 1606] was the fifth Guru of the Sikhs, born at Goindval. He was the youngest of the three sons of Guru Ram Das, the fourth Sikh Guru.

Guru Arjan Dev finished the construction of the Harimandir Sahib, the Golden Temple, and compiled the first Sikh scripture, known as the Adi Granth. Shortly after he became the first martyr of the Sikh religion, which formed a turning point in the development of the faith.
